docs.lead_paragraph: The Sioux Falls City Council has passed an ordinance banning cage fighting in parks and city-owned facilities and requiring organizers to get a permit and have security officers and a paramedic present at fights. Under the ordinance, passed Monday, organizers are not allowed to make more than 25 percent of their income from alcohol sales, and they must have at least $1 million in liability insurance and cover medical expenses of fighters who are injured and do not have health insurance. Cage fighting involves two people who fight in a chain-link cage using any combination of boxing, kickboxing, martial arts or wrestling. Gretchen Ruethling (NYT)

headline.main: National Briefing | Plains: South Dakota: Limits On Cage Fighting

docs.snippet: The Sioux Falls City Council has passed an ordinance banning cage fighting in parks and city-owned facilities and requiring organizers to get a permit and have security officers and a paramedic present at fights. Under the ordinance, passed Monday,...

docs.lead_paragraph: In a series of rulings, federal judges are limiting the ability of poor people to turn to the courts to fight for Medicaid benefits to which they believe they are entitled. The judges, following guidance from the Supreme Court, are ruling that Medicaid recipients cannot use the courts to enforce a provision of the law that says they should have the same access to health care services as ''the general population.''

headline.main: Rulings Trim Legal Leeway Given Medicaid Recipients

docs.abstract: Federal judges' rulings are limiting ability of poor people to turn to courts to fight for Medicaid benefits to which they believe they are entitled; judges, following guidance from Supreme Court, rule that Medicaid recipients cannot cite provision of law that says they should have same access to health care services as 'general population'; rulings, in more than dozen cases, affect millions of people and involve wide range of services(M)
docs.snippet: In a series of rulings, federal judges are limiting the ability of poor people to turn to the courts to fight for Medicaid benefits.

docs.lead_paragraph: Is the right to stiff the waiter as American as apple pie? Thomas Keller, chef at the extravagantly priced Per Se restaurant in the Time Warner Center in Manhattan, does not think so. Indeed, he is taking tipping off the table at Per Se starting next month and replacing it with a flat service fee of 20 percent.

headline.main: What, No Tip? Service Charge Faces Struggle At Restaurants

docs.snippet: American diners relish the power of the tip to reward or punish their servers, and the servers want them to have it.
